overview_summary: All five neighbors have no documented public stance on the proposed development, leaving their positions classified as unknown. Their community influence appears limited; apart from one neighbor who co-runs a local farm auction (moderate social ties), the others do not hold prominent public roles or influence.

neighbors.name: Beau & Jessica Martin
neighbors.claims: Beau Martin helps run Martin Auction Company, a family-owned farm auction service based near Orleans ([martin-auctionco.com](https://martin-auctionco.com/about-us/#:~:text=In%202004%2C%20Lyle%20and%20son%2C,the%20clerking%20for%20items%20sold)). The Martin family has farmed and raised cattle west of Orleans for decades, and Beau continues that tradition on his own farm northwest of town ([martin-auctionco.com](https://martin-auctionco.com/about-us/#:~:text=Lyle%20and%20Judy%20Martin%20were,Lance%2C%20DeLanie%2C%20Wyatt%20and%20Berkley)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a respected farm community member (e.g., his father or a Farm Bureau peer) introduce the project to Beau, emphasizing how it can align with preserving their family farm legacy and support the local agricultural economy.

neighbors.name: Carol A. Wells
neighbors.claims: Carol A. Wells owns property in the Orleans area, but no evidence was found of her serving in local government or speaking publicly on development issues ([harlancounty.ne.gov](https://harlancounty.ne.gov/webpages/links/public_notices.html#:~:text=Public%20Notices%20,in%20the%20Community%20Room%20located)). She does not appear in available county records or news reports regarding civic engagement or land-use debates ([harlancounty.ne.gov](https://harlancounty.ne.gov/webpages/links/public_notices.html#:~:text=Public%20Notices%20,in%20the%20Community%20Room%20located)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Outreach should be one-on-one and neighborly. A personal visit to introduce the project and listen to any concerns would be appropriate, as she is a private landowner with no known organizational affiliations.

neighbors.name: Bart A. & Jill R. Woodward
neighbors.claims: Bart and Jill Woodward are listed as landowners in Harlan County but do not hold any public offices or prominent roles in community groups, according to local records ([harlancounty.ne.gov](https://harlancounty.ne.gov/webpages/links/public_notices.html#:~:text=Public%20Notices%20,in%20the%20Community%20Room%20located)). No public statements or participation by the Woodwards in development or energy issues could be identified in news or meeting archives ([harlancounty.ne.gov](https://harlancounty.ne.gov/webpages/links/public_notices.html#:~:text=Public%20Notices%20,in%20the%20Community%20Room%20located)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the Woodwards through an informal neighbor-to-neighbor approach. Emphasize listening to their concerns about farming operations, and possibly involve an agricultural extension agent or mutual acquaintance to build trust.

neighbors.name: Jesse R. & Jill C. Hays
neighbors.claims: Jesse and Jill Hays own multiple parcels near Orleans, but there is no record of them participating in local government or public forums on land development ([harlancounty.ne.gov](https://harlancounty.ne.gov/webpages/links/public_notices.html#:~:text=Public%20Notices%20,in%20the%20Community%20Room%20located)). They have kept a low public profile, with no mentions in recent county board minutes or local media regarding community issues ([harlancounty.ne.gov](https://harlancounty.ne.gov/webpages/links/public_notices.html#:~:text=Public%20Notices%20,in%20the%20Community%20Room%20located)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach the Hays family personally via a friendly introduction from a mutual farming community contact. Discuss the project in terms of practical impacts (roads, drainage) and reassure them by showing an understanding of rural landowner concerns.

neighbors.name: Gary L. & James G. Stoelting
neighbors.claims: Brothers Gary and James Stoelting operate “Stoelting Brothers,” a small corn-farming partnership based in Orleans ([naicslist.com](https://naicslist.com/company-profile/stoelting-brothers-orleans-ne-68966#:~:text=Stoelting%20Brothers%20is%20a%20specialized,team%20of%20approximately%202%20employees)). Aside from running their farm business, the Stoeltings are not publicly active in civic affairs, and there are no public records of them taking positions on local development projects ([naicslist.com](https://naicslist.com/company-profile/stoelting-brothers-orleans-ne-68966#:~:text=Stoelting%20Brothers%20is%20a%20specialized,team%20of%20approximately%202%20employees)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have an agriculture-oriented discussion with the Stoelting brothers. A peer farmer or local ag extension representative could help explain how the project will protect farmland integrity and address any crop or soil concerns they may have.
